nova/compute/resource_tracker.py.message: Always assumed these were enums, as this is just a string what's stopping us from using `reverting` here and updating to `reverted` on the source once things are actually complete?

> The status is already 'reverting' at this point. 

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/adbc94f8cdb/nova/compute/api.py#L3774-L3775
ACK and we can't add reverting to the list in [2] because we need to wait until we actually drop the claim on the dest here right?
ACK thanks

The status is already 'reverting' at this point. Even if it weren't, setting it here would perpetuate the race. This task would drop the usage but the periodic task, running between this and the source setting the status to 'reverted', would simply re-add it. The only migration's we don't track are those whose status is one of: confirmed, reverted, failed, completed, cancelled, and done. [1][2] I'll acknowledge that this isn't the greatest UX in the world, but it's good enough and fixes the race.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/adbc94f8cdb/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L923
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/adbc94f8cdb/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L3280

Correct. If we added that to the list, we'd introduce a new race whereby running the periodic task between setting the status and calling 'drop_move_claim()' would result in the resource usage for that claim being "dropped" twice (it wouldn't be accounted for after the periodic task run, and we'd still blindly try to decrement usage afterwards)

nova/api/openstack/compute/services.py.message: I don't see how this is related, seems placementclient.detete_resource_provider() uses service uuid as the rp_uuid for filtering, I don't see how chaning the service hostname or driver will affect this. Also, even if this is somehow the case, we should try to find the correct rp in placement and delete it, otherwise we will be having two orphan RP record.

Actually AFAICS placementclient.delete_resource_provider is not using the service uuid as the filter. It's using the uuid of the compute_node as the rp_uuid. (See: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#n2268) if that compute node object is not existing anymore, there is no chance to lookup any associated resource providers anymore I think.

But if that compute_node object really got remove due to a change of the hostname then the resource providers should have been cleaned up already here:
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/compute/manager.py#n7770

So unless I am overlooking something we should be fine here.

I found a way to reproduce this bug in all_in_one environment：
1) Make sure the nova-conductor and nova-compute services are running on the same node.
2) Delete nova-conductor service.
    openstack compute service delete <nova-conductor service id>
3) Delete nova-compute service.
    openstack compute service delete <nova-compute service id>

While deleting nova-compute service at step 3, we will get the error.

The reason is that when we deleted nova-conductor service, the corresponding ComputeNode record will be deleted too.
https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#n406

And then we deleted nova-compute service later, nova can't get service.compute_node anymore.

This will always fail before call `delete_resource_provider` as `service.compute_node` will try to load object attr by host but in fact not in database. The case is really low frequency but can reproduce. I hit this bug when try to change compute driver from libvirt to ironic.

nova/compute/resource_tracker.py.message: Can we use one DB call get all the migraiton object we need here?
do you mean add 'error' into the status filter in this function? or introduce a new db call?
I guess add the filter to 'objects.MigrationList.get_by_filters' is workable. Anyway, it is wasteful to use two DB calls to get the data, special in large scale cluster.

Yeah, I agree with that one db call is enough.
But I'm still not sure how to define 'in progress', because I see there are two db functions defined about in-progress migration, they seems different.

1. migration_get_in_progress_by_host_and_node
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L3151
It takes a complementary set of some status as in-progress status.

2. migration_get_in_progress_by_instance
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L3167
It takes some specific status as in-progress status. But obviously, it doesn't include other status like 'migrating','confirming','reverting' and so on.

Which one should I take for my filters if I use get_by_filters.

Shouldn't this be a new API in the 'nova.db.api' and 'nova.db.sqlalchemy.api'?

This also feels like it could be a separate change. You're stating that we should included those in the 'error' state because they likely haven't been cleaned up and therefore are using inventory, yeah? That seems reasonable so is it possible to do that change without any of the other changes here?

I prefer not to seperating, since we track them then we should have other way(periodic task change) to cleanup them, these changes should be proposed together to make it work properly.

introducing a new API sounds nice, current way looks a little ugly.
This needs a comment
Done

Done
should we stop vpmem cleanup if delete instance files failed?

I could do something similar with a simple vnic_type=direct port. If I fast enough with an attach - detach sequence then the state of the PCI device goes from available -> claimed but does not go to allocated . If I hit detach when the PCI device still just in claimed then the PCI device is not freed. Instead after a periodic run it goes to allocated regardless of the successful detach. If it was the last PCI device available on the host then the subsequent attach will fail as there is no free device for it. 

I will look into the code to find the reason...

I think I'm solved this by not just claiming the pci device but also allocating it during the interface attach call. I cannot reproduce the problem any more. @Sean: could you please check if you can still see the problem with the latest PS?
So far I could not reproduce this issue with vnic_type=direct ports http://paste.openstack.org/show/796216/

I think this is a rabbit hole. Even if the MAC is left on the VF after the neutron port in unbound, that VF is in DOWN state. Whenever that VF is pulled UP, the client that does the UPing should make sure the the VF is configured properly. OpenStack does that during bind so I think we are safe.

With vnic_type=macvtap I think I see what you saw.
1) booted a VM with a macvtap interface. it set the MAC of the neutron port to the interface
2) I deleted the VM and the interface on the host still has the MAC of the neutron port

With this procedure I can create a situation when a host has more VF interfaces with the same MAC, even.

However this is not caused by the current patch. As I can create this issue with simply booting and deleting VMs. So something with the macvtap handling might be incorrect in the baseline. I probably need help with this from you, Sean.
Here I'm planning to blacklisting the VF driver on my host as it might be that when the VF is attached back to the host the driver on the host does the cleanup of the MAC in my case.

matching based only on MAC address is not enough the current complex condition is added to fix a bug where two interfaces had the same MAC https://review.opendev.org/#/c/372243/25

I go into the direction where both LibvirtConfigGuestHostdevPCI and LibvirtConfigGuestInterface knows how to match vif generated config with libvirt returned config.

by this I was able to resolve the issue with direct-physical detach

Moreover the detach interface for a macvtap port does not remove the device definition of the interface from the domain xml either. This explains why libvirt does not remove the tap from the host.

There is a WARNING during detach of a macvtap port:

Jul 24 10:55:17 master0 nova-compute[38941]: WARNING nova.virt.libvirt.driver [None req-ed883189-378f-4712-af4b-e43cfa1fd31b admin admin] [instance: 9fe5ecca-9213-424c-8fe3-c64e4ae62cdd] Detaching interface fa:16:3e:67:31:da failed because the device is no longer found on the guest.

Originating from [1]. So I assume there is a bug in the libvirt driver regarding macvtap detach.

The nova.network.neutron.API.create_resource_requests() called by _allocate_pci_device_for_interface_attach() actually does what you described. Sure it does a bit more as it can handle networks not just ports as it is used during boot. I would like to re-use as much as possible from create_resource_requests() as 1) it apparently does the right thing 2) it is used and tested during boot so we know it works 3) if something new needs to be supported regarding neutron ports then it will anyhow need to be added both to the boot and to the interface attach code path, so I like if such addition can be done in a single place.


Also please note that the now unused self.network_api.allocate_port_for_instance() also created the NetworkRequestsList and called allocate_for_instance() in the baseline. What I did is that I removed the allocate_port_for_instance() helper and I create the NetworkRequestsList directly here, so it can also be reused for the create_resource_requests() call as well.

nova/virt/libvirt/config.py.message: it might be nice to add a comment with the bit widths of each field. unfuturnetly it does not look like the typing module support fixed width integers so unfortunetlly we cant enforce that with mypy or other typechecking.
These are stored as strings so typing module cannot help anyway. I've added some comment base on your comment.

technically the function is in octal so this shoudl be 3
the slot and bugs are also not technically in hex.

the pci address is a 32 bit int encoded as follows

domain (16 bits), bus (8 bits), device (5 bits) and function (3 bits).


so technically you coudld decode it more correctly as follows

 return (int(self.domain, 16) == int(other.domain, 16) and
                    int(self.bus, 8) == int(other.bus, 8) and
                    int(self.slot, 5) == int(other.slot, 5) and
                    int(self.function, 3) == int(other.function, 3))

what you have will technically work but it will decode invalid pci addresses too.

we dont really do the righ think in the format_dom below either but it technialy will work if we dont exceed the value that fit in those bit limits.

Libvirt returns the address pieces as hexa strings:

<address domain='0x0000' bus='0x81' slot='0x00' function='0x1'/>

And int('0x1', 3) is an error as 0x is a prefix for a hexa number.

>>> int('0x1', 3)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 3: '0x1'

So I do have to parse the strings as hexas.

Alternatively I could do string manipulation. Something like:

    @staticmethod
    def _equal_without_hexa_prefix(a, b):
        return a.split('x')[-1] == b.split('x')[-1]

But don't really like this alternative.
its fine parsing in as hex sting will work.

These are "extras" for Taskflow.
You would include them like this:
taskflow[redis,zookeeper]>=4.1.0

Assuming you need both. These could also be declared as extras on the octavia package to allow users to pick which one is needed at Octavia install time.

See:
https://github.com/openstack/taskflow/blob/master/setup.cfg#L57
https://setuptools.readthedocs.io/en/latest/setuptools.html#declaring-extras-optional-features-with-their-own-dependencies
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0508/#extras

If we declare redis and zookeeper exats in Octavia and taskflow bumps required version - we may end up with broken code?
I think both redis and zookeeper should be extras for Octavia. Keeping the version in sync is an issue, but we should have a gate job running with the versions listed in extras to catch any issues.

A whitelist wouldn't buy us anything; Nova doesn't use / enable these events.  Checking with DanPB, he said we added support for these `perf` events in the first place to enable some non-Nova project.

I asked on the upstream list if anyone is using the `perf` events at all in Nova, so far I hear only crickets chirping:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-July/007521.html — [ops][nova] Quick show of hands: any use Intel (non-CMT) `perf` events?

+1

Actually, would it be possible to get a whitelist?

> Shouldn't we explicitly filter out those broken flags even if
 > libvirt says it supports them (via the 'hasattr' check above)...or
 > am I misreading this?

Notice that we have never explicitly validated any other events either. This patch is simply removing the mapping of these CMT events to CPU features.

IMHO, any validation of events is a separate problem, unrelated to this patch.

(Also see my response to John below—I don't think anyone is using these `perf` events at all.  Refer to the upstream thread linked.)

But it's modifying the XML based on their presence, no? Just above this, we have the function that's actually using this function:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/19.0.0/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L4870-L4881

That includes a check to see if the perf event is supported:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/19.0.0/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L4883-L4902

For most of these, we simply check if the libvirt module has the attribute specified 'LIBVIRT_PERF_EVENT_PREFIX + event.upper()' attribute, so a user could specify 'alignment_faults' and we'd check to see if the libvirt library exposes 'VIR_PERF_PARAM_ALIGNMENT_FAULTS' (which is does on my local machine). However, for these specific options, we were special casing them to make sure they'd never report as enabled and therefore they'd never be added to the list of supported events:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/19.0.0/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L4879-L4880

and it feels like we're regressing here, because we will go back to passing these options through when we weren't doing that previously so it feels like we should either (a) keep this check forever or (b) drop the whole perf event feature itself entirely. If this can't break users, why were we ever warning on this stuff in the first place?

(Sorry for the delayed response; was buried in other things.)

Yes, you make a good point.  We should continue to maintain the blacklist.

How about we just turn the warning into an error below?

Looking at the code as it existed before the commit that originally added what you're removing here, fc4794acc6b13afade1bb72a1ae9f574707d2f0d, it seems we were previously blacklisting these flags if the feature was not supported by the host CPU. After that commit, we started blacklisting them entirely, and now with this change we stop blacklisting them at all. We don't necessarily need a whitelist for all options (since that could be a very complex endeavor) but I do think we should at least continue to blacklist these known broken event types or explain very clearly why blacklisting isn't needed now even though it was needed before.

reference/projects.yaml.message:
This should be on the kuryr-kubernetes deliverable.

However, I guess it's an open question whether this should have a tag at all, given that AIUI it runs purely on the k8s side. The main thing for a starter kit is to tell users what they need to install on the OpenStack side. But there is value in highlighting the usefulness of the project (maybe we would do the same for cloud-provider-openstack if it were an official OpenStack project?).

Ah, that's true, the fun fact about kuryr-kubernetes is that in regular use case it's not installed on OpenStack side, but on the K8s cluster. OpenStack just needs to fulfill all the requirements - trunk ports enabled in Neutron, access to Octavia.

I've left this in for now on the grounds that we might want to include it in any integrated testing program. But I could just as easily see us leaving it out on the grounds that it's not something the cloud *operator* needs to worry about (in principle, anyway).

reference/tags/starter-kit_kubernetes-in.message: nit: Just to clarify terminology, "Neutron's OVN provider driver for Octavia".
https://docs.openstack.org/ovn-octavia-provider/latest/admin/driver.html
Thanks, will update in next patchset.
I don't think this is necessarily true. I would argue we should remove the "but would be a very heavyweight solution in many use cases." statement.

1 loadbalancer per Service of LoadBalancer type is something that is typically implemented for most of the cloud providers. Using ingress controller can't replace services usage.

We (cloud-provider-openstack) do have some feature requests that asking to re-use loadbalancer for services, so things will probably change in future.

> 1. There are more than just the Amphora and OVN driver available
 > for Octavia and things change over time,
 > so why put opinionated verbiage in this document? It's disrespectful to our partner
 > vendors.

I agree that there's a risk of this becoming out of date. I did say 'other backends' so as to acknowledge the fact that Amphora is not the only driver, but I gather from what you're saying that maybe this comment is actually specific to the Amphora driver?

 > 2. OpenShift is shipping with the Amphora driver in this role today
 > and has been for a while.

OpenShift networking folks wrote the OVN driver specifically because they wanted to avoid this problem, and IIUC the only reason they're not using it is because the move to OVN has not yet occurred.

 > 3. One VM per service is only the side effect of how someone wrote
 > the Go based cloud provider for k8s.

From a user's perspective it doesn't really matter if it could have been implemented differently but wasn't.

 > There is no reason you are
 > required to run one load balancer (and thus a VM) per service. For
 > these internal east-west connections, it would probably be best to
 > use one Octavia load balancer per cluster or application and stack
 > the ports (or use SNI) like most of the other k8s drivers do.

This is interesting because it appears to be different to my understanding of the history, which was that e.g. in the AWS cloud provider each LoadBalancer Service also created an ELB (cost: $16 per month just for existing... which I'd call pretty heavyweight), and that was solved not by changing the driver but by creating the Ingress API in k8s instead so that HTTP-based services could all share a single ELB.

e.g. here's Google Cloud talking about when you'd use a LoadBalancer Service:
https://medium.com/google-cloud/kubernetes-nodeport-vs-loadbalancer-vs-ingress-when-should-i-use-what-922f010849e0#d489
"The big downside is that each service you expose with a LoadBalancer will get its own IP address, and you have to pay for a LoadBalancer per exposed service, which can get expensive!"

Is this no longer the case?

It looks to me like EKS also has a network load balancer (similar in approach to the OVN driver for Octavia, or to MetalLB) that they offer to allow you to avoid creating an ELB in these types of cases: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/services-networking/service/#aws-nlb-support

The approach you suggest doesn't seem possible in general because Services operate at Layer 4, so you don't know if they will use TLS, let alone SNI, and the user gets to select the ports so they may conflict. With the right selection of hacky platform-specific annotations it's obviously possible for a subset (but probably the same subset that an Ingress would work for).

 > No
 > one goes out and buys another load balancer appliance per service.
 > I just don't see how this opinion about a service/tool being used
 > incorrectly adds value to the document.

By helping to guide users toward using tools correctly? i.e. use an Ingress where possible, otherwise select the OVN driver if you have it, otherwise evaluate all of your options.

 > 4. Some would argue that the amphora's small footprint and full L7
 > content switching capability is far from heavyweight.

In many contexts that would be a good argument, but if e.g. you're comparing to a couple of iptables rules, it's definitely heavier.

It's not a criticism of a tool to state which problems it is best suited for solving. Tools don't have to be all things to all people to be valuable.

AIUI the main advantage of using an Ingress is that you can serve a bunch of different endpoints (including across different domains) from a single load balancer (one or more VMs). If you create k8s Services of type LoadBalancer, you end up creating an Octavia load balancer for each one. So with the Amphora driver that means at least 1 VM (more if you want HA) per Service. Is that accurate?

That sounds pretty heavyweight to me; a typical k8s cluster would generally contain a lot of Services. I'd imagine most users would want to rely on the Ingress controller as much as possible, and fall back on something like L2-mode MetalLB for other cases if the OVN driver isn't available.

The "OpenShift networking folks" didn't write the OVN provider driver, my team did. But that also doesn't matter here.

A service, by definition is a DNS name and port. SNI/host routing is commonly used.

I'm not saying you should remove the guidance that the OVN provider driver is a good option. I am simply saying that I think it is rude/disrespectful to make that blanket statement that every other product than OVN is "very heavyweight". I prefer an open and welcoming community that supports varying viewpoints, and ecosystem of vendor partners, and supports giving users options.

> I'm not saying you should remove the guidance that the OVN provider
 > driver is a good option. I am simply saying that I think it is
 > rude/disrespectful to make that blanket statement that every other
 > product than OVN is "very heavyweight". I prefer an open and
 > welcoming community that supports varying viewpoints, and ecosystem
 > of vendor partners, and supports giving users options.

I'm definitely not trying to be disrespectful to anyone or their work. If there's anything to be criticised here, it's the k8s API, which is a wasteland of BS cloud-specific annotations that make applications completely non-portable.

Where I'm coming from is that network load balancers and actual load balancers are completely different things. For most tasks, network load balancers simply do not cut it. But if you have a lot of tasks for which a network load balancer *is* sufficient, you'll probably want to use one because it consumes a lot less resources.

Setting those expectations realistically for users upfront helps avoid disappointments that could reflect badly on OpenStack.

I'll try to find some more diplomatic wording that hopefully everyone can be happy with.

My response is four fold:
1. There are more than just the Amphora and OVN driver available for Octavia and things change over time, so why put opinionated verbiage in this document? It's disrespectful to our partner vendors.
2. OpenShift is shipping with the Amphora driver in this role today and has been for a while.
3. One VM per service is only the side effect of how someone wrote the Go based cloud provider for k8s. There is no reason you are required to run one load balancer (and thus a VM) per service. For these internal east-west connections, it would probably be best to use one Octavia load balancer per cluster or application and stack the ports (or use SNI) like most of the other k8s drivers do. No one goes out and buys another load balancer appliance per service. I just don't see how this opinion about a service/tool being used incorrectly adds value to the document.
4. Some would argue that the amphora's small footprint and full L7 content switching capability is far from heavyweight.

I've said my piece on this, I just don't think this part of the sentence adds value to the document.
Is this link missing its trailing underbar?
nit: provide
I dunno, I think there's plenty of cases of wanting RWO for statefulsets running on top of Kubernetes.  With the Cinder CSI plugin, the time to move a PV/PVC is relatively short.

Manila has no Cinder or Nova dependency -- one Manila back end out of 30+ does (the so-called "generic" back end).  This Cinder with Nova Service VM back end is useful for test purposes -- and for general OpenStack integration testing :D -- but as I think you know it has many limitations and we do not recommend it for production deployments.  Production deployments who want open source software defined storage use Gluster or Ceph.  And there are proprietary back ends from the major vendors and others.

Again, depending on the goal of the starter kit, including Cinder may be appropriate, but not because Manila requires Cinder.
I think what's tricky is Manila generally will need some form of storage, and if you're relying on using Cinder with service VMs, you've kinda gone back to a minimum requirement?

Manila CSI supports other access modes than RWX, like RWO, as well.  Is the intent of the starter kits to provide the minimum needed (in which case Manila CSI covers all the access modes) or to provide a richer set of OpenStack projects?

I'm certainly not trying to exclude Cinder CSI in the latter case.

Technically it's kuryr-kubernetes, "kuryr" was the project targeting Docker. It's also worth saying that when using kuryr-kubernetes you'll have it handle Services as well and that's done through Octavia. If Octavia on the cluster is using Amphora, this means each Service is an Amphora VM and that might be a trade off that people will not take.

Obviously ovn-octavia solves it.
It uses the OpenStack Cloud Controller to do this, or it has an independent implementation of the Load Balancer part of that?
It has it's own implementation of a controller watching Services and Endpoints, so independent.
It might be worth pointing out https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/secrets-store-csi-driver - this may provide a way for us to use Barbican or Vault as a better replacement for etcd stored secrets
I hadn't heard of that, but it sounds... appalling?
there is ongoing effort to support multiattach and will be part of the 1.19, If thats the only reason then can be reconsidered too.

It's a good point, but I would be very hesitant to consider multiattach support the answer for this. From the cinder side, it still comes down to RWO. Somewhere in the stack, something needs to do the fencing necessary to ensure multiple write sources are coordinated to make sure writes don't conflict with one another.

So multiattach support takes care of some of the plumbing to get there, but I think greatly increases the complexity to make sure there is no data corruption. A good thing that can be done, but IMO, probably not something we want to get into in a starter kit configuration.

K8s would need enhancement to install some kind of clustered file system (and manage it across worker nodes) instead of just the current choices -- ext4 and xfs -- both of which are node-local filesystems.  Just mounting these to more than one node can result in file system corruption even if end users aren't doing I/O at the same time on multiple nodes.
hmm, got it. Thanks Sean

cinder/volume/drivers/lvm.py.message: I don't think this needs to be in the LVM driver.

volume type extra-spec without prefix "capabilities:" will be treated as filter. See: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/scheduler/filters/capabilities_filter.py#L62

So extra-spec "cacheable" will be treated as filter. As discussed in spec, some backends like nfs and rbd will not be supported. So I'm trying to enable the supported backends explicitly. Any backends not marked "cacheable=True" will not be supported by default. It is like white list mode. We may can go through backends drivers and add more drivers as supported later in a following patch.

cinder/volume/manager.py.message:
do you want a boolean here?  (compare to line 2627, and also line 77 in test_attachments_manager.py)  I think this is a string if the key is set.

If so, you got lucky in test_attachment_update.  You may want to add a special-purpose test in test_attachments_manager.py to check to make sure you get 'cacheable': True in the connection_info (or maybe there's a connection info test somewhere you can adapt).

Yes, you are correct, should be boolean here. I use this value in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/663549/6/os_brick/caches/__init__.py@62, and in my tests I set to '<is> True' or unset, so did not find this potential issue(any string will be treated as True, even it's not '<is> True'), thanks Brian

I think you could simplify this to:

  cacheable == '<is> True'

This forces the cacheable flag on for every driver in cinder.
I think we should leave this up to the driver, just like we do in the case of setting the multiattach flag.

See my comment in driver.py about how you can address Walt's point.

Walt brings up an interesting point, but I am worried about the opposite situation, namely, what if the driver sets cacheable = True?  While it may be safe for a driver to turn off caching all the time, we cannot allow it to turn caching on all the time, because that's supposed to be controlled by the operator via the extra-specs.  So I think you need to add a check here for when the conn_info['data']['cacheable'] is defined.  Something like this:

  if typeid:
      cacheable = volume_types.get_volume_type_extra_specs(
          typeid, key='cacheable')
      if conn_info['data'].get('cacheable') is not None:
          driver_setting = bool(conn_info['data']['cacheable'])
          # override a True driver_setting but respect False
          conn_info['data']['cacheable'] = (driver_setting and
                                            (cacheable == '<is> True'))
      else:
          conn_info['data']['cacheable'] = (cacheable == '<is> True')

There's probably a better way to do it, but you can figure that out when you write the tests :).
I think it's safer to rely on the driver to set this flag.

just loops over the bining reponce values and updates the vif objects with the reponce vlaues

does vrouter actully impleiment the multiple port bidnign feature? initally the neutron change wehre ment to be don above the ml2 driver layear in the the service plugin but the driver actully need to implement a few functrions.

vrouter has its own ml2 plugin/driver espcially wehn used with contrail. i suspect that it either does not support multiple port and neutron is incorrectly still reporting binding-extended extentions or there is a bug in the vrouter nueton plugin.

the nova and neutron specs were co written making it the responceibleity of the the ml2 driver and/or core plugin to report support for biding-extended.

before we intoduced this exention allow multiple port bindings (one for the destination and another for the source)
the port binding were not updated until after the migration

this lead to long delays and prevented you form migrating between say ovs with ip tabels firewall and ovs with conntrack since the vif detail would not be avaiable when generating the xml on the source node.

there was a very deliberate effort by both the nova and neutron communities to develop a new protocol for port binding, we can differ on if it was a poor design or not (i disagree with your statement) the alternitive was to force all out of tree driver to adopt the new portcol in queens as we could not adress the gaps in migration without breaking them otherwiwse. 

it was and is expected that all driver will eventually suport the extnsion but having it be a spererate exteion allows a phased approch.

we have two code paths in nova for live migration,
we still support the legacy flow which does not update the vif detail until after the migration and we also support the modern workflow of using two bindings. it looks like the vrouter ml2 driver or core plugin has never adopted the modern workflow and the ml2 driver has a but where it is not filtering out support for it.

there are some other feature in nova that also only work if you support this extension. namely cross cell cold migration and resize.

you have not confirmed what vrouter backend you are using by the way, is it the core plugin or the ml2 driver.
if its the ml2 driver the fix is trivial you need to filter the supported extensions in the ml2 driver to remove binding_extended from the list.

given its been two years since this extension was introduced 
and that all ml2 driver and core plugins were expected to eventually  adopt it i find it odd that this has not already been fixed but ill bring it up with some nuetron folks i work with and ill see if we can poush to move this to a core extetion and required for all backend in W. that would allow us to drop the legacy code path in nova removing the conditionality.

i just spend the last couple of hours talking to artom about his bug and this one and we have reconfimred that

if self.network_api.supports_port_binding_extension(ctxt)

look, vif mandatory attributes, u statement, are set conditionally depending on obscure neutron-based check for network_api.supports_port_binding_extension which means that these vif attributes are optional actually because otherwise there should be an unconditional execution path setting their values. worse the check means all the vifs are not eligible without supporting some extension - indicator of a poor design. and the last one, the migration task fails with an unhandled exception which also manifests some deep problem with overall code.

ok so there is a bug then. the code that is failing shoudl only be running if bining dextend is used so we need to find and fix that.

get_dest_vif is only used for _update_vif_xml

and _update_vif_xml should only be called when using binding-extended

this is what 

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/718dcf76de7ccdced97937075d8aa45c36ab1552/nova/virt/libvirt/migration.py#L64-L65

is ment to be guarding althoug its indriect

so for some reason we are entering 

https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L8932-L8955

which means vifs is set in migrate_data
but that should only  be set if binding_extended is used.


vif is only ever set here 

https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/nova/compute/manager.py#L7654-L7656

check_can_live_migrate_destination is called here

https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/nova/conductor/tasks/live_migrate.py#L361


if we are doing sriov migration which is not your case we 
before we call check_can_live_migrate_destination we run  self._check_can_migrate_pci(self.source, destination)

which checks for the port binding extention

https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/nova/conductor/tasks/live_migrate.py#L250-L254

in the vrouter case the port binding extenion is checked after the vifs object is populated in the migrate data.

https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/nova/conductor/tasks/live_migrate.py#L371

so we need to add an else staement that removes the vifs
from self.migrate_data when its not support to make sure that code path that depens on multiple port binding and uses
the presence fo the vifs to determin if ti should run is not run.

that is the root cause of the bug you are hitting.
ill push a trival testing patch for that and you can see if it works for you

Storing an exception in a local variable tends to cause a reference loop that requires garbage collection, since the exception's traceback usually references the stack frame that contains the local variable. We delete it to break the reference loop and help ensure that as much of the heap as possible can be deleted by reference counting without resorting to garbage collection.
